transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Hi everyone! Welcome back to our session. I hope you all had a good week. Before we get started, I just want to check in—how’s everyone feeling today?

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I’m okay, I guess. Bit tired from school.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: Same here. Lots of homework.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: I’m alright. Feeling a little stressed though.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: I’m good, just busy with football practice.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: Feeling a bit anxious, honestly.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: I’m fine, nothing much to report.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Thanks for sharing, everyone. That’s completely normal. Some of you are feeling stressed or tired, and that’s okay. Today we’re going to talk about something called a growth mindset. Has anyone heard that term before?

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I think so? Is it like believing you can get better at something if you try?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yes, exactly, Jabari. A growth mindset is the idea that your abilities and intelligence can develop with effort, learning, and practice. It’s different from a fixed mindset, which assumes you’re either smart or not, and there’s nothing you can do to change that.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: So it’s basically like saying your brain is like a muscle you can train?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yes, Amani, that’s a great way to put it. Your brain can grow stronger when you challenge it and learn from mistakes.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: But what if you fail at something a lot? Doesn’t that mean you’re just bad at it?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Not necessarily, Keziah. A growth mindset sees failure as part of learning. Each time you make a mistake, it’s an opportunity to figure out what didn’t work and try a new strategy.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: That sounds nice in theory, but it’s hard to think that way when you’re failing in front of everyone.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: I hear you, Leo. It can feel embarrassing or discouraging. The key is to focus on what you can control—your effort, your persistence, and how you respond to setbacks. That’s what actually makes your brain grow.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: So basically, if I’m struggling in math, it doesn’t mean I’m stupid?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly, Sara. Struggling just shows that your brain is working on new connections. With practice, your understanding can improve.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: I’ve always thought people are just naturally good or bad at stuff. So this changes that idea?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yes, Sam. Growth mindset says that anyone can improve with effort and the right strategies.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: Can you give an example? Like, something that actually happened?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Sure. Think of a professional athlete. They didn’t start off being the best. They practiced every day, learned from coaches, and even from losses. That practice is what helped them grow their skills.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: So it’s like Messi practicing free kicks every day, not just being born good at them.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly, Amani. Even the most talented people improve through consistent effort and learning.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: Okay, but what about school? I study a lot sometimes and still get bad grades.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Good question, Keziah. Growth mindset isn’t just about working hard—it’s about working smart. That means using strategies, asking for help, reflecting on mistakes, and adjusting how you study.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: That makes sense. So failing a test isn’t the end of the world; it’s just feedback.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly, Leo. Feedback is a tool for growth, not a judgment on who you are.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: I think I can see that. But it’s still frustrating.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Absolutely, Sara. Feeling frustrated is normal. Growth mindset doesn’t remove the frustration, but it helps you use it as a signal to try a different approach.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: So it’s like a mental switch? Instead of thinking 'I’m bad at this,' you think 'I can get better if I try differently'?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly, Sam. That shift in perspective can change how you approach challenges.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I guess I never really thought about it that way. I usually just give up if I’m bad at something.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That’s okay, Jabari. Many people start that way. The important part is recognizing that you can try again and use different strategies.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: Can we do an activity to practice this?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yes! I thought we could try a short reflection exercise. Everyone, think of something you’ve struggled with recently. It could be school, sports, or even a hobby. Write down one thing that didn’t go as planned.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: Okay, I’ll do that. I struggled with my last football game.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: I’ll write down math homework I didn’t understand.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: I’ll do that too. My drawing didn’t turn out like I wanted.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: I’ll pick my piano practice. I messed up a song.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I’ll write about my science project. Didn’t get the results I wanted.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: I struggled with learning a new language word today.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Great, now look at what you wrote. Next to each struggle, write one thing you could try differently next time, or one small step that could help you improve.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: For football, maybe I can practice the plays slowly before trying full speed.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: For math, I could ask my teacher for extra examples or practice problems.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: For drawing, I could break it down into smaller parts instead of trying the whole thing at once.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: I could practice the tricky parts of my piano song separately.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I could redo my experiment in smaller steps to understand each part.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: I can review new words in short sessions every day instead of cramming.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Excellent ideas, everyone. That’s using a growth mindset. You’re focusing on the effort and strategies that can help you improve, instead of thinking failure means you’re not capable.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: I see how that could actually help. Makes it less overwhelming.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: Yeah, it feels more manageable to take small steps.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: I like that. Makes mistakes feel less scary.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: I think I get it now. Effort plus strategy, not just hoping to be naturally good.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I’ll try that next time I fail something. Focus on what I can control.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: Me too. It’s like turning frustration into action.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly. That’s the goal—using challenges as opportunities to grow. For homework this week, I want you to practice noticing when you’re thinking in a fixed mindset, and try to reframe it into a growth mindset. Maybe even keep a small journal.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: Do we have to write a lot?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Just a few sentences each day is enough. The point is to notice your thoughts and try a small change.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: That seems doable.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: Yeah, I can do that.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: Same here.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I’ll try.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: Me too.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Great. Let’s take a few minutes to share one example of how you might do that in real life this week. Who wants to go first?

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: I’ll go. If I mess up a football drill, I’ll try breaking it down and practicing slowly instead of getting frustrated.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: I’ll ask for extra help in math rather than assuming I’m bad at it.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: I’ll try to redo my drawings in smaller parts when I feel frustrated.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: I’ll focus on tricky parts of songs instead of getting overwhelmed by the whole piece.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I’ll redo small parts of my science project if it doesn’t work the first time.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: I’ll review new words in short daily sessions instead of cramming and giving up.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Excellent sharing. Remember, it’s about effort, reflection, and strategy. Keep practicing and notice your growth over time.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: I think I understand it better now.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: Yeah, it feels more practical.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: I’ll try to keep that mindset this week.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: Me too.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I’ll give it a shot.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: Same here.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Wonderful. That’s all for today. Remember, a growth mindset isn’t about being perfect—it’s about keeping at it, learning from mistakes, and believing you can improve. Thanks for your participation, everyone. See you next session!
